items.title: Regular expression in AnsiToWin32 exhibits catastrophic backtracking
items.body:
Hi there! I've been working on a new Python static analysis tool called [Dlint](https://github.com/dlint-py/dlint). Most recently I've been working on a rule that searches for regular expression denial-of-service: [DUO138](https://github.com/dlint-py/dlint/blob/master/docs/linters/DUO138.md). When running this rule against your codebase I found a violation:

```
$ python -m flake8 --select=DUO138 colorama/
colorama/ansitowin32.py:71:19: DUO138 catastrophic "re" usage - denial-of-service possible
```

After further investigation, it appears the violation in `colorama/ansitowin32.py` is a true positive. If we dig in further:

```python
class AnsiToWin32(object):
    ...
    ANSI_OSC_RE = re.compile('\001?\033\\]((?:.|;)*?)(\x07)\002?')
```

The violation occurs due to `'\001?\033\\]((?:.|;)*?)(\x07)\002?'`. In particular, this portion of the expression: `(?:.|;)*`. This is due to [mutually inclusive alternation](https://www.regular-expressions.info/redos.html) within a quantifier. Since `.` and `;` have character overlap. We can confirm the bug with a specially crafted string and the following code:

```python
from colorama import ansitowin32
ansitowin32.AnsiToWin32.ANSI_OSC_RE.match('\033]' + ';' * 64 + '\x08')
...Spins...
```

To fix the issue we should avoid the character overlap between `.` and `;`. One way to accomplish this is with the following expression:

```python
ANSI_OSC_RE = re.compile('\001?\033\\]((?:[^;]|;)*?)(\x07)\002?')
```

Hope this is helpful, let me know if you have any questions!

items.title: colorama.init(autoreset=True) breaks argparse
items.body:
Consider the following snippet:

```python3
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import argparse
import colorama
#colorama.init(autoreset=True)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument('-o', '--output', type=argparse.FileType('w'), default='-')
    args = parser.parse_args()
    with args.output as fp:
        fp.write('hello world\n')
```

When running, it prints `hello world` as supposed:

```sh
$ ./spam.py
hello world
```

However, uncommenting `colorama.init(autoreset=True)` breaks the script when entering the `with` context:

```sh
$ ./spam.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "spam.py", line 10, in <module>
    with args.output as fp:
AttributeError: __enter__
```

I uncovered this issue in a setup where another package pulls `colorama` and calls `colorama.init(autoreset=True)` under the hood, with a side-effect of breaking my own code. The reason is `StreamWrapper` wraps `io.TextIOWrapper`, but doesn't provide access to the `__enter__` and `__exit__` magic methods.

May I suggest adding `__enter__` and `__exit__` magic methods to `StreamWrapper`?

```python3
class StreamWrapper(object):
    '''
    Wraps a stream (such as stdout), acting as a transparent proxy for all
    attribute access apart from method 'write()', which is delegated to our
    Converter instance.
    '''

    def __init__(self, wrapped, converter):
        # double-underscore everything to prevent clashes with names of
        # attributes on the wrapped stream object.
        self.__wrapped = wrapped
        self.__convertor = converter

    def __getattr__(self, name):
        return getattr(self.__wrapped, name)

    def __enter__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        return self.__wrapped.__enter__(*args, **kwargs)

    def __exit__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        return self.__wrapped.__exit__(*args, **kwargs)

    def write(self, text):
        self.__convertor.write(text)
```
Right now, it's either that (monkeypatch `StreamWrapper` with the above class if importable) or checking for private attributes in the package:

```python3
out = args.output._StreamWrapper__wrapped if hasattr(args.output, '_StreamWrapper__wrapped') else args.output
with out as fp:
    fp.write('hello world\n')
```

items.title: Using colorama with `tee` means no color, is there a way to force it on?
items.body:
We have an app using colorama. We are running the app like;
```bash
app.py 2>&1 | tee output.log
```

This causes all colors to go away :-(

I'm pretty sure it is because colorama is detecting that it is writing to a pipe rather than a terminal and thus disabling the color output. This would normally be a *good* thing, but in our use case it would be good if there was a way to force colorama to assume its on a good terminal.

I was hoping that `colorama.init()` would have a `force_color=True` type argument, but sadly I did not find such a thing.

I can't seem to find in colorama were this detection code in colorama is to add this feature? Can you point me in the right direction and I'll send a pull request.

items.title: Drop support for EOL Python versions?
items.body:
Is there any interest in dropping support for old Python versions? When they reach EOL that means they're no longer receiving security updates.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/34263159-38b766bc-e677-11e7-918b-54bc889cfff0.png)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPython#Version_history

---

README says "Tested on Python 2.5.5, 2.6.5, 2.7, 3.1.2, 3.2, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5 and 3.6.".

setup.py has the same versions:
```
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 2',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 2.5',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 2.6',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 2.7',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.1',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.2',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.3',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.4',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.5',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.6',
```

Only these are tested on Travis:
```
  - "2.7"
  - "3.6"
  - "3.5"
  - "3.4"
  - "3.3"
  - "3.2"
```

---

Here's the pip installs for colorama from PyPI for the last month (via `pypinfo --percent --pip --markdown colorama pyversion`)

| python_version | percent | download_count |
| -------------- | ------: | -------------: |
| 2.7            |   91.9% |      8,195,681 |
| 3.6            |    3.8% |        337,152 |
| 3.5            |    2.4% |        211,580 |
| 2.6            |    1.1% |         94,341 |
| 3.4            |    0.8% |         69,467 |
| 3.3            |    0.0% |          3,901 |
| 3.7            |    0.0% |          1,996 |
| 3.2            |    0.0% |              8 |
| None           |    0.0% |              1 |

From these numbers, it looks like EOL versions 2.5, 2.6, 3,1, 3.2 and 3.3 could safely be dropped.

This would allow the code to be modernised and ease the maintenance burden somewhat.

Thoughts?

UnboundLocalError in winterm.erase_screen()
items.body:
*Originally reported here: https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/5263*

Thank you for your work on `colorama`!

The way the code is set up at the moment, if the `mode` parameter is not in the expected [0-2] range, no value will be assigned to the `cells_to_erase` and `from_coord` variables and an `UnboundLocalError` will be raised.

While an invalid mode is certainly an error case, it would be helpful to have it raise a more explicit exception.

items.title: Bright background may produce undesired behavior on Windows
items.body:
Hello.

I know that `LIGHT_EX` colors are not part of the standard, but I noticed a strange behavior while using it so I prefer to report it.

```python
from colorama import Fore, Back, Style, init
init()
rst, lr, r, b = Style.RESET_ALL, Back.LIGHTRED_EX, Fore.RED, Fore.BLUE
msg = "{1}back-light-red{0} 0 {2}red{0} 0 {3}blue{0}".format(rst, lr, r, b)
print(msg)
```

This produces:

![1504351426-screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4193924/29995106-0a39444a-8fe2-11e7-962e-261412593cee.png)

As you can see, once a background light color has been used, it infects other colors.

The bug does not occur with the light colors in foreground, nor with normal colors in background.

The bug may be "reset" if a normal background color is used.

```python
from colorama import Fore, Back, Style, init
init()
rst, lr, br, b = Style.RESET_ALL, Back.LIGHTRED_EX, Back.RED, Fore.BLUE
msg = "{1}back-light-red{0} 0 {2}red{0} 0 {3}blue{0}".format(rst, lr, br, b)
print(msg)
```
![1504351934-screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4193924/29995163-3b281b66-8fe3-11e7-98eb-45c5a16a693f.png)

This is tested with the default terminal of Windows 10, on Python 3.6.2 and colorama 0.3.9.
Also, I tried with the Linux bash terminal of Windows 10 and it worked perfectly fine.

Is it a known bug (which could explain why light colors are not documented)? Do you know if this can be fixed or if it is because of the Windows terminal?

I got error with Python 3.5/3.6 in Windows 10 and roll back to 0.3.6 to fix this issue...

items.title: autoreset=True doesn't work for file output (Python 3.6.0, Ubuntu)
items.body:
I'm not sure if this is a known/expected limitation of autoreset, but it seems to fail to provide the reset codes after each print() in the case of buffer/file output.   

Example:
```
>>> from io import StringIO
>>> from colorama import init, Fore
>>> init(autoreset=True)
>>> print(Fore.GREEN + "Green") ; print("Not Green")
```
Works as expected, yet:
```
>>> buf = StringIO()
>>> print(Fore.GREEN + "Green", file=buf) ; print("Not Green", file=buf)
>>> buf.seek(0)
0
>>> print(buf.read())
```
Both lines are green.

items.title: Why doesn't it works with 'input' method under Windows?
items.body:
Under linux, not only the 'print' method but 'input' can render color, while Windows only works with 'print'.
I think it's better to keep them coincident.

items.title: MacOS Background Color not resetting
items.body: I am attempting to change the background color at different parts throughout a string. The desired effect I want is something like this: (_photoshopped_) However, when I test the code, this is what actually appears. After researching this bug around the internet, I have determined that it is a pretty well known bug with macOS terminals. There were several methods of fixing the issue, but none that I knew how to do in python, especially in regards to this library. Thus, I am asking here if anyone knows a way to fix this background color bleed bug from within python in a way that works with the cross platform functionality of colorama. Thanks for your help, TPG

items.title: Can not display color in PyCharm using default init()
items.body:
[PyCharm](https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/) is a widely used python IDE, which has a built-in python console.
However, the default init() function doesn't works very well in it's console. See example below:

``` python
import colorama

colorama.init()
print(colorama.Fore.GREEN + "hello world-green" + colorama.Fore.RESET)
print(colorama.Fore.RED + "hello world-red" + colorama.Fore.RESET)
```

![sc 2016-10-07_16-53-03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15957250/19184567/678437d0-8cb0-11e6-8401-6bebf2144ace.png)

And we have to set `convert=False` and `strip=False` to make it works in PyCharm console

``` python
import os
import colorama

if 'PYCHARM_HOSTED' in os.environ:
    convert = False  # in PyCharm, we should disable convert
    strip = False
    print("Hi! You are using PyCharm")
else:
    convert = None
    strip = None

colorama.init(convert=convert, strip=strip)
print(colorama.Fore.GREEN + "hello world-green" + colorama.Fore.RESET)
print(colorama.Fore.RED + "hello world-red" + colorama.Fore.RESET)
```

![sc 2016-10-07_16-54-21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15957250/19184604/90123e18-8cb0-11e6-9db3-c8e82b3fe9fa.png)

> **PYCHARM_HOSTED**  
> It's an special environment that only occurs in PyCharm,
> see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29777737/how-to-check-if-python-unit-test-started-in-pycharm-or-not

items.title: Output is not colored on Windows when redirecting standard output to a file
items.body:
Hi there!

Thanks for this awesome project :-)

I've recently hit a case where I redirected the standard output to a file and all logs to standard error get these strange symbols:

```
←[33mWARNING←[0m:←[1mroot←[0m:←[33mApplied some throttling!←[0m
```

It seems like colorama doesn't detect that there is a tty when only the standard error stream is a tty.

I started digging through the code and noticed this:

```
# colorama/win32.py

def winapi_test():
    handle = handles[STDOUT]
    csbi = CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO()
    success = _GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo(
        handle, byref(csbi))
    return bool(success)
```

If I change the code to this, then it works for me:

```
def _winapi_test(handle):
    csbi = CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO()
    success = _GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo(
        handle, byref(csbi))
    return bool(success)

def winapi_test():
    return any(_winapi_test(h) for h in handles.values())
```

Any chance you're willing to accept a patch for this?

Thanks!

items.title: Question: Is it possible to convert back to ANSI codes from the win32 calls?
items.body:
### Summary:

I'm wondering: Is it possible to convert from the win32 calls back to the ANSI color codes? Are the win32 calls even something that exists within the string?

(Note, I'm not asking about doing so within a single program: there's `deinit()` for that.)

Based on the discussion in the [Appveyor color issue](http://help.appveyor.com/discussions/suggestions/197-support-ansi-color-codes), I'm assuming that it's not possible. Is that correct?

> See the comments by Nathan Stocks (maintainer of [green](https://github.com/CleanCut/green)) - he had to turn **off** colorama so that ANSI codes would be sent to the server so that Appveyor could then convert them
### Reason for the Question:

I'm using a self-hosted [Gitlab](http://about.gitlab.com) instance and a [GitLab-CI Runner](https://about.gitlab.com/gitlab-ci/) running in a Windows environment, so I use Colorama to make the pretty colors happen. However, the web interface for GitLab is a unix terminal emulator. The CI runner pipes output to both STDOUT (Windows) and to this web interface (linux)  (at least that's how I believe it works - haven't confirmed yet).

What this means is that colors work locally (windows), but are not displayed correctly on the web UI ([GitLab Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ci-multi-runner/issues/332). I'm trying to help the GitLab guys out with fixing this issue, and one solution is to take any win32 calls and convert them back to ANSI on their end.
#### Windows CMD terminal:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5386897/13360329/8d290b3a-dc6d-11e5-9c6a-2fc8d9b19aa6.png)
#### GitLab Web Interface

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5386897/13360298/59bf5e8e-dc6d-11e5-96b2-5f0d099b71c0.png)

items.title: Consider no-tty handling, again
items.body:
Following issue #47, reset codes are now emitted even when redirection is taking place (i.e., no tty).
Since colorama calls reset_all when the program terminates, there is now an undesired effect when using colorama and redirection -- a reset code will be emitted along with the redirected output. See:

```
> python -c "import colorama; colorama.init(); print('a')" | xargs python -c "import sys; print(sys.argv)"
['-c', 'a', '\x1b[0m']
```

In other words, commands that take output from scripts with colorama will now get an extra ANSI reset code, which they probably don't expect.
- The bahavior before fixing #47: On Linux when there is no tty, reset_all codes were stripped but other ANSI codes were not stripped
- The current behavior: On Linux when there is no tty, nothing is stripped and both reset codes and other color codes are written to the redirected output
- New, suggested behavior: On Linux when there is no tty, all ANSI codes should be stripped

Note that on Windows when there is no tty, all ANSI codes are already stripped.
@tartley noted in #47 that colorama should behave like other unix utilities (like 'ls') and output color codes only on tty. I disagreed, but I changed my mind now.

The change in the code is simple, if I'm not mistaken: change the default `strip` value from:

   strip = conversion_supported

to 

```
strip = conversion_supported or not is_a_tty(wrapped)
```

The impact is that the behavior of colorama on Linux with redirection will change.
Does this make sense? Does everyone agree that colorama should strip the color codes and the reset codes when there is no tty? Does the code change look right?
@tartley, your thoughts?

items.title: support context manager syntax
items.body:
Reported by steve at the domain 3xile dot com, Aug 8, 2011
It'd be nice to turn colorized output on and off with `with` rather than either init() or writing by hand, especially when other modules want to modify sys.stdout.  Here's an example implementation:

```
import sys
from colorama import Fore, AnsiToWin32

class ConvertedOutput(object):
    def __init__(self, *AnsiToWin32Args, **kwargs):
        self._AnsiArgs = AnsiToWin32Args
        self._set_stderr = kwargs.get('stderr', None)
    def __enter__(self):
        self._stdout = sys.stdout
        sys.stdout   = AnsiToWin32(sys.stdout, *self._AnsiArgs)
        if self._set_stderr:
            sys.stderr = AnsiToWin32(sys.stderr, *self._AnsiArgs)
    def __exit__(self, type, value, traceback):
        sys.stdout = self._stdout
```

And example usage:

```
with ConvertedOutput():
    print('%sThis text is red%s' % (Fore.RED, Fore.RESET))

print('%sThis text is surrounded by junk%s' % (Fore.RED, Fore.RESET))
```

Migrated from https://code.google.com/p/colorama/issues/detail?id=28&can=1

items.title: play nicely with other stdout/stderr wrappers
items.body:
Migrated from https://code.google.com/p/colorama/issues/detail?id=41
Reported by eallik, Jan 21, 2013

Take a look at the wrapper provided at http://stackoverflow.com/a/3259271/247623 --it reliably enables Unicode output on cmd.exe; unquestionably useful. However, it turns out that colorama does not work out of the box in combination with that wrapper.

The reasons for this are:
- first of all, colorama needs to be activated after that wrapper because the other wrapper is more low level/fundamental
- colorama remembers the `orig_stdout` and `orig_stderr` references in its `initialise.py` at import time, thus, by the time `init()` is called, any wrappings that have taken place before `import colorama` and `init()` are effectively cancelled/ignored
- colorama does not convert ANSI codes for streams who are not `.isatty() == True`; I'm not sure why such check was implemented in the first place, but it looks to me that colorama works perfectly well with streams that do not have such property.

The current workaround is to manually update `orig_stdout` and `orig_stderr` with fresh values from `sys.stdout` and `sys.stderr` respectively, and also do `sys.stdout.isatty = sys.stderr.isatty = lambda: True` to satisfy the `is_a_tty` check in `ansitowin32.py`. However, it would be nice if colorama did not require such workaround to compose nicely with other wrappers.

Reported by wbax...@google.com, Feb 10 (5 days ago)
Somewhat related to Issue 41, but if you have replaced sys.stdout with something else (like StringIO in order to capture output for unit testing purposes), then the wrapping that colorama does exposes an interface that differs from that of the object you set sys.stdout to. items.title: v0.3.2 crashes when clearing console on Windows7 / Python3.4
items.body:
Received this helpful email:

Good day-
I have tried to use the colorama-0.3.2 on a Windows 7 PC, using Python 3.4, but my program would crash when attempting to clear the console.  I examined colorama's winterm.py file and found the following pieces of problem code:

---

Line 111: coord_screen = win32.COORD(0,0)
Problem: There is no win32.COORD() function.
Solution: Replace line 111 with the following:
    coord_screen = win32.GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo(handle).dwCursorPosition
    coord_screen.Y = coord_screen.X = 0
Why: The first line gets a coordinate object; the second sets it to (0,0).

There likely is a single call that generates the coordinate object, but I don't know what that call would be, and presume I would need to import an additional library (which-ever that would be) to access that call.  Instead I get an existing coordinate object and re-position it

---

Line 116: win32.FillConsoleOutputCharacter(handle, ' ', dw_con_size, coord_screen)
Problem: In Python 3.x, character strings are Unicode (thus 2-bytes per character), not one byte per character.
Solution: change ' ' to b' '
Why: By explicitly declaring single byte character string, the needed conversion is explicitly imposed.

---

Line 120: win32.SetConsoleCursorPosition(handle, (coord_screen.X, coord_screen.Y))
Problem: The console position (0,0) doesn't seem to work when setting the console cursor position.
Solution:
        win32.SetConsoleCursorPosition(handle, (1,1))
Why: It appears that SetConsoleCursorPosition() uses 1-basis postioning rather than 0-basis; by explicitly moving the cursor to (1,1), the desired "set to home position" now works.

---

With these changes, colorama now works on my Windows PC when using Python 3.4.  I do not have an installation of Python 2.x, nor do I have a non-Windows PC to test my changes, but I hope this will help correct an otherwise very useful Python library.

Regards-
Richard Miner
richardminer@frontier.com

items.title: Don't depend to ctypes on Linux
items.body:
Hi,

On CPython buildbot "FreeBSD 7.2, the compilation of the ctypes module fails. The pip module cannot be used because it imports colorama which uses ctypes for its win32 module, and the win32 module is always imported, even on Linux. IMO it would be better to not import this module on Linux to avoid the dependency to ctypes.

I also reported the issue to pip:
https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/2079

Test output on the buildbot:
#

items.title: Doesn't work on IronPython
items.body:
Within the colorama package, the file "initialise.py" at line 56, it should be: 

```
on_windows = sys.platform.startswith('win') or sys.platform.startswith('cli')
```

instead of:

```
on_windows = sys.platform.startswith('win')
```

items.title: Support for python 3.2.5
items.body:
```
from colorama import Fore, Back, Style
# ...
    print Back.YELLOW + Fore.BLACK + 'Initiating connection...' + Style.RESET_ALL
             ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

items.title: Highlight background of text
items.body: Using `print Back.YELLOW + 'initiating connection...'` will change the background of the entire line in the terminal. Is there a way to only highlight the text background?

items.title: Report issues on Google code, not here
items.body:
This project is recently migrated from Google code.

The issues list currently still resides there until I migrate it over to github.

Please report any issues there for now:

```
https://code.google.com/p/colorama/issues/list
```

Thanks.

items.title: init doesn't work on Cygwin
items.body:
Hi,
Should the bugs from Google Code be re-reported?
We're still waiting for a fix to issue #16:
https://code.google.com/p/colorama/issues/detail?id=16

When calling 'init' under Cygwin, colorama stops working (it works if we don't call it). Our current work around is:

```
if 'TERM' not in environ:  # this is how we recognize real Windows (init should only be called there)
        init()
```
